Comments_List:
Strengths: This course is very useful to learn more about advanced EPI methods and help students think critically about study design and data analysis.
Weakness: Answers to questions are not posted in canvas.

The topics on homework assignments are good and thought-provoking but lectures are convoluted and spend a tremendous amount of time going over equations and derivations rather than proper application of the models. I wish the homeworks were actually graded and that the course focused more on them. The statistical programming language used is GLIM which is challenging to read/interpret so I really wished there was a TA or someone to translate or review homework assignments in R or SAS. The lecture material just does not translate well to actual assignments or applications and the final reflected very little of the material.

It was really cool to see how a lot of things I took for granted in Epi I and Epi II were "proven" in Epi III using biostatistical methods, and then evaluating those results with a grain (okay, more like a bucket) of salt. But I think a lot of the material went over my head, especially since the premise of the course was that most of the material wouldn't crystallize until months in the future... And I wish our homeworks gave us more space to be skeptical about data analysis and interpretation.

Strengths: more reinforcement of epidemiology
Weakness: no office hours, need time between discussion and lecture

Strengths: Dr. Risch is an excellent instructor and gives in-depth creative ideas to EPI study and research.
Weakness: some handwriting in lectures' PDF is hard to recognize. If possible, PDF made by keyboard input is helpful.
Dr. Harvey is extremely knowledgeable but I wish he upgraded the course to make the topics a bit more modern, used R or SAS, or assigned more applied work throughout the semester.
I liked the end-of-class tangents, as it brought real-world experiences to the admittedly rather dry biostats.
Hes incredibly knowledgeable and a great source to learn further epidemiological methods from.
This course is great and extremely useful to students whose career goal is to be academia. I highly recommend it.
Would not recommend unless you've been dying to know the underlying derivations and every single equation for epi models.

If you care about why epi works the way it does, this could be a worthwhile class. But if you're not interested in methodology and just want to apply the basics, then maybe this might not be a good use of your course registration.
Its difficult but very good for students who want to pursue epidemiology.
